Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Chemical Research Addressing Energy and Environmental Challenges
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry a the National Science Foundation supports a Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) Site led by Professors Mary E. Williams and Landy K. Blasdel both of Pennsylvania State University. The Site will continue its highly successful program that focuses on chemical research that addresses energy and environmental challenges. Each year, the REU Site will introduce nine undergraduate students to a ten-week summer research experience. The goal is to inspire students to continue their scientific careers by providing an exciting and relevant chemical research experience with an outstanding group of research mentors and support structure. In this way the Site will attract and prepare a diversified pool of talented young researchers and future professionals.

REU students will gain experience in cutting-edge research using state of the art equipment at Pennsylvania State University. Graduate students and faculty will mentor the new young investigators. Prior to the REU summer program, mentors will be trained on how to effectively direct and advise the REU students. The broader impacts of the Penn State Chemistry REU site are to provide training and preparation to the future generation of researchers by educating a well-prepared, diverse, and scientifically literate workforce, and to contribute by advancing energy and environmental research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Chemistry department at Penn State annually hosted an REU site focused on chemistry topics in environmental and energy research each year of the project period, supporting the summer research experience for a total of 30 undergraduate students. Students participated full time, working as members of teams of graduate student, postdoc, and faculty researchers. An additional 20 students participated in the chemistry summer research program, expanding the impact of the NSF grant to additional students by giving them access to programmatic activities even when their stipend was not funded by NSF.

REU participants gathered weekly for professional development workshop and seminars, which them opportunities to learn more about broader research topics, and build their professional and scholarly skill set. Topics in the workshops included poster presentations, effective seminar strategies, diversity and inclusion, etc.  

Our REU program assessment activities involve delivery of surveys to participants at the beginning, middle, and end of the summer research experience. We also solicit feedback from participants a year after their participation, to learn about their career and graduate school plans and to obtain some qualitative information about the impact of their Penn State Chemistry REU experience. Formative information from the surveys informs us on our students' preparation and progress, and has led us to place additional focus in the professional development workshops on applying to graduate schools; and to add training for graduate student and postdoc mentors on effective mentoring.

 

The broader impacts of the Penn State Chemistry REU program are primarily in fostering the development and learning of undergraduates in chemistry, to encourage them to further their education in graduate programs and to prepare them to be successful in graduate school.  We have already seen a large percentage (75%) are currently attending or plan to attend graduate programs in chemistry (and related fields). Many have hit the ground running and are publishing! The REU program is thus contributing to the skilled technical workforce in chemistry research, and giving students unique opportunities to learn about the intersection of chemistry and energy and environmental research.
